title: Kington Walks

images.title: Tom Courtney / Kington
images.caption: A photo of Kington from Offa's Dyke Path from the north looking south.

images.title: Bob Embleton / River Arrow
images.caption: River Arrow. Looking downstream from the bridge on Bridge Street. An important source of power for milling wheat.

images.title: Chris Heaton / Back Brook
images.caption: Back Brook Tributary of the River Arrow, in Kington. This is where the Offa's Dyke National Trail crosses this watercourse next to the A44 bypass.

images.title: Chris Heaton / Offa's Dyke on Rushock Hill
images.caption: Offa's Dyke on Rushock Hill. For Offa's Dyke National Trail walkers going north, this is truly an emotional moment - after 54 miles absence the ancient earthworks reappear and accompany the path at last.

images.title: Chris Heaton / On the flank of Herrock Hill
images.caption: On the flank of Herrock Hill. Offa's Dyke National Trail descending down the eastern flank of Herrock Hill towards the valley of Hindwell Brook. This part of the walk is of the highest quality.

images.title: Chris Heaton / Offa's Dyke Trail below Herrock Hill
images.caption: Offa's Dyke Trail below Herrock Hill. The trail takes a sharp right at the saddle, but the Dyke itself curves round onto the summit - some feat of engineering for the Dark Ages.

images.title: Andrew Jones / Hergest Croft - ornamental orchard
images.caption: Hergest Croft gardens just to the west of the town- ornamental orchard Spring colour amongst the old orchard trees

description: This Herefordshire based market town lies very close to the Welsh border. It's location next to Offa's Dyke and the wonderful Hergest Ridge make it a fine base for walking. There are also two significant waymarked footpaths passing through the town and the gorgeous Hergest Croft Gardens to visit. This circular walk around the town visits Rushock Hill, Herrock Hill and the River Arrow. It uses sections of the Mortimer Trail and the Offa's Dyke Path , two waymarked footpaths which run through the area. Start the walk in the town where you can pick up the Offa's Dyke Path. Follow the waymarked trail north and it will take you to Bradnor Green before climbing to Rushock Hill and Herrock Hill. You'll climb to over 1200ft in this area, with fine views over England and Wales to enjoy. You then turn east passing Knill Garraway Wood and picking up the Mortimer Trail. Follow the trail south past Rushock to Portway. Here you follow a footpath west along the River Arrow to return you to the town.
